nodes.text: We have enough data now to forecast the balance sheet for our planned expansion. Recall from

with the percent of sales method that forecasting the balance sheet helps us identify any future funding needs because the balance sheet must balance. Here, we have explicitly planned for the funding of the expansion in 2020. Nonetheless, we can check to make sure that our debt issue will be enough and then forecast past the expansion to see if we will need any future financing.

shows the balance sheet for 2019 and 2020 filled in with the information we have so far. The only piece of information we are missing is the dividend amount, so we assume for now that we will not pay any dividends in 2020.

config.activityTitle: Pro Forma Balance Sheet for KMS, 2020

nodes.text: As we can see from the column for 2020 in the pro forma balance sheet, KMS’s balance sheet does not initially balance: the liabilities and equity are greater than the assets. In

, KMS faced the opposite situation—its assets were greater than its liabilities and equity—and this told KMS’s managers that they needed external financing. When liabilities and equity are greater than the assets, we have generated more cash than we had planned to consume and we need to decide what to do with it. KMS’s options are:
Build-up extra cash reserves (which would increase the cash account to bring assets in line with liabilities and equity).
Pay down (retire) some of its debt.
Let’s assume KMS’s managers choose to distribute the excess as dividends. The excess is the amount by which liabilities and equity exceeds assets:

nodes.text: New financing is needed—the firm must reduce dividends, borrow, or issue new equity to fund the shortfall.
Excess cash is available—the firm can retain it as extra cash reserves (thus increasing assets), pay dividends, or reduce external financing by retiring debt or repurchasing shares.
